intro: Lupinus tucumanensis, commonly known as Tucumán lupine, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Bolivia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its tall, erect growth habit and showy, sparsely hairy flowers. The plant typically produces clusters of blue to purple pea-like flowers, which bloom in late summer. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several oval-shaped leaflets, and it thrives in well-drained soils. Lupinus tucumanensis is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas.
